item.title: Millennial Spending
item.description: Sankey Diagrams Sankey Diagrams are a popular way of showing flows. Lately they’ve become pretty popular for showing budgets since they allow you to show the hierarchical relationships and proportions within groups pretty intuitively. Below, I just wanted to provide a really quick example of one of these using data from the Consumer Expenditure Surveys. Speifically, the data used come from the 2017 Generational table to show how the average Millennial spends their money.

item.title: Nonessential Spending and Bad Data
item.description: Introduction You’ve probably seen a headline making its way around the internet: “Americans spend $18,000 a year on nonessentials!” The Motley Fool via USA Today recently published their own version “You don’t need that: Average American spends almost $18,000 a year on nonessentials.” Unfortunately, I haven’t been able to find a lot of information about where this particular factoid came from, but most sources agree that it comes from a poll conducted by OnePoll and paid for by the insurance company Ladder.
